channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Hong Kong Protest Leaders Are Prevented From Flying to Beijing
item.description: The students calling for free elections had proposed a meeting with China’s prime minister, but they were turned away Saturday at the Hong Kong airport.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and ALAN WONG

item.title: Obama Offers Assurances of U.S. Shift Toward Asia
item.description: Visiting Australia, President Obama said the United States could be a force for order as Asia faced threats like a nuclear-armed North Korea and disputes between China and its neighbors.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Alexander Grothendieck, Math Enigma, Dies at 86
item.description: His gift for abstraction excavated new ground in algebraic geometry and supplied a theoretical foundation for the solving of some of the most vexing conundrums of modern mathematics.
item.dc:creator: By BRUCE WEBER and JULIE REHMEYER

item.title: Spacecraft on Comet Drills for Data as Its Power Fades
item.description: The Philae lander performed two tricky maneuvers on Friday: drilling into the comet’s rocky surface and rotating itself to try to catch more sunlight to recharge its batteries.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: City in Ukraine Tied to Masochism Finds Link Painful, Sure, but Some Like It
item.description: Residents of the western Ukrainian city of Lviv are of two minds on the reputation of Leopold von Sacher-Masoch.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A waitress at the Masoch Cafe in Lviv, Ukraine, pouring a drink into the mouth of a customer voluntarily tied to a chair.

item.title: Yazidi Girls Seized by ISIS Speak Out After Escape
item.description: A few of the thousands of young women from the minority Yazidi religion who were kidnapped by the Islamic State told of a systemized industry of slavery.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Rare Vaccine-Derived Polio Discovered in 2 Countries
item.description: Cases of paralysis caused by mutating polio vaccine have been found in South Sudan and Madagascar, the World Health Organization said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Nigeria: Gunmen Take Town Where Girls Were Seized
item.description: Gunmen have seized Chibok, forcing thousands of people to flee the town where the group Boko Haram kidnapped nearly 300 schoolgirls in April, a local official said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Algeria: President Hospitalized in France, Reports Say
item.description: President Abdelaziz Bouteflika, who was hospitalized for months last year after a stroke, has been admitted to a French hospital in the city of Grenoble, news agencies reported Friday, citing French police officials.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: British Royal Couple Planning New York Visit for December
item.description: Prince William and Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, will visit the Sept. 11 memorial and stop at a youth organization during a three-day stay in the city.
item.dc:creator: By MATT FLEGENHEIMER
item.media:description: Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, and Prince William will spend three days in New York next month.

item.title: Islamic State Says It Plans to Issue Its Own Currency
item.description: The leaders of the Islamic State have created their own currency, part of a grandiose plan to restore the caliphate era that dominated the Middle East more than 1,300 years ago.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Open Source: A New Holiday Tradition for the Dutch: The Debate Over Blackface
item.description: A celebration of St. Nicholas in the Netherlands now includes an annual fight over the traditional depiction of his dark-skinned helper, Black Pete.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Ton van Kesteren, Matthijs Jansen and Dennis Ram of the far-right Dutch Freedom Party attended a meeting in Groningen this month dressed as Black Pete.

item.title: Opinion: The Comfort Women and Japan’s War on Truth
item.description: The Abe government is determined to rewrite the imperial military's history of wartime sexual slavery.
item.dc:creator: By MINDY KOTLER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. & A.: Kung Tsui-chang on Life as the Heir to Confucius
item.description: Kung Tsui-chang, a 39-year-old businessman in Taiwan who is the 79th-generation direct descendant of Confucius, discusses what it was like growing up in the family of such a famous figure.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Kung Tsui-chang, right, at a ceremony in the Confucius Temple in Taipei, Taiwan, on Sept. 28, 2007, honoring the ancient Chinese philosopher.

item.title: French Authorities Hunt What May Be a Wildcat Near Disneyland
item.description: A large animal on the loose on the outskirts of Paris is not a tiger but another species of feline, news agencies reported.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:credit: Olivier Lejeune/Le Parisien/Maxppp, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Officials estimated that a large wildcat on the loose on the outskirts of Paris weighed as much as 150 pounds, based on the size of its tracks.

item.title: Eurozone Eked Out Growth in Third Quarter
item.description: The euro economy grew 0.6 percent in the third quarter on an annualized basis, raising concern that the Continent’s troubles will ripple out.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: French job seekers checking postings last month. The Eurozone’s third-quarter growth, just 0.6 percent, raises concern abroad.

item.title: E.U. Accuses Starbucks and Netherlands of Making Unfair Tax Deal
item.description: The arrangement helped lower taxes for the coffee company, creating unfair advantages over other European Union countries, authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: A branch of Starbucks in central London. Starbucks announced in April that it was moving its European headquarters to Britain.

item.title: The Tax Attraction Between Starbucks and the Netherlands
item.description: As global authorities ramp up efforts to close tax loopholes, companies are lobbying against proposed reforms.
item.category: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM
item.media:description: Microsoft's headquarters in Luxembourg. American companies are fighting efforts in Europe to reverse favorable tax deals.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: In a Soft-Spoken Romanian Prosecutor, Some See an ‘Earthquake’
item.description: Those caught in the sights of Laura Codruta Kovesi, who, as head of Romania’s anticorruption agency, is leading a vigorous drive against graft, denounce her as a Stalinist.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Cristian Movila for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laura Codruta Kovesi, 41, leads Romania’s National Anticorruption Directorate.

item.title: Afghan President Out to Ease Relations on Visit to Pakistan
item.description: President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan will meet with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif and Pakistani military officials to discuss curbing terrorism on the shared border.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan arrived in Rawalpindi, Pakistan, on Friday.

item.title: China’s Rise as Arms Supplier Is Put on Display
item.description: The world’s fourth-largest exporter of arms is now encouraging smaller private domestic companies to enter the field.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINA LARSON
item.media:description: A model poses next to missiles from the "Beijing Symbol of Power Technology Development Company," at Airshow China.

item.title: Indian State Recalls Pills Linked to Sterilization Deaths
item.description: Officials in Chhattisgarh State issued an urgent warning to practitioners to cease distribution of the antibiotic ciprofloxacin after at least 15 deaths were linked to contaminated pills.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ and ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Women who underwent tubal ligation procedures at a government-run “sterilization camp” in Chhattisgarh State, India.

item.title: U.S. to Give $3 Billion to Climate Fund to Help Poor Nations, and Spur Rich Ones
item.description: The pledge, on the heels of an announcement that the United States and China will commit to curbing greenhouse gas emissions, is expected at the Group of 20 summit meeting this weekend.
item.dc:creator: By CORAL DAVENPORT and MARK LANDLER
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A climate change accord to be signed in Paris next year would commit major economies to cutting carbon emissions from sources such as coal-fired power plants, like this one in Ghent, Ky.

item.title: Nicola Sturgeon Becomes Leader of Scottish National Party
item.description: Ms. Sturgeon moved into the job after 10 years as deputy leader and immediately suggested that the party might seek a new referendum on independence.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Obama and Aung San Suu Kyi Meet Again, With Battle Scars
item.description: President Obama met with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi in a show of support for Myanmar’s reform process, despite evidence of the nation’s backsliding.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama met with Burmese youth Friday at Yangon University. Myanmar’s leader, Thein Sein, has been pursuing political and economic reforms.
